column11: Joe Rinaldi|"Lady and the Tramp represented two ""firsts"" for Disney: It was the studio's first Cinemascope animated feature
column12: and it was their first full-length cartoon based on an original story rather than an established ""classic"". Lady is the pampered female dog belonging to Jim Dear and Darling. When her human masters bring a baby into the house
column13: Lady feels she's being eased out; and when Darling's insufferable Aunt Sarah introduces her nasty twin Siamese cats into the fold
column14: Lady is certain that she's no longer welcome. The cats wreak all manner of havoc
column15: for which Lady is blamed. After the poor dog is fitted with a muzzle
column17: only to run across the path of the Tramp
column18: a raffish male dog from the ""wrong"" side of town. The Tramp helps Lady remove her muzzle
column19: then takes her out on a night on the town
column20: culminating in a romantic spaghetti dinner
column21: courtesy of a pair of dog-loving Italian waiters. After their idyllic evening together
column22: Lady decides that it's her duty to protect Darling's baby from those duplicitous Siamese felines. On her way home
column23: Lady is captured and thrown in the dog pound. Here she learns from a loose-living mutt named Peg that The Tramp is a canine rake. Disillusioned
column24: Lady is more than happy to be returned to her humans
column25: even though it means that she'll be chained up at the insistence of Aunt Sarah. Tramp comes into Lady's yard to apologize
column26: but she wants no part of him. Suddenly
column28: vicious rat breaks into the house
column29: threatening the baby. Lady breaks loose
column31: runs into the house to protect the infant. When the dust settles
column32: it appears to Aunt Sarah that Tramp has tried to attack the child. That's when Lady's faithful friends Jock the bloodhound and Trusty the scottie swing into action
column33: rescuing Tramp from the dogcatcher. Once Jim Dear and Darling are convinced that Tramp is a hero
column34: he is invited to stay...and come next Christmas
column35: there's a whole flock of little Ladies and Tramps gathered around the family. Beyond the usual excellent animation and visual effects
column36: the principal selling card of Lady and the Tramp is its music. Many of the songs were performed and co-written by Peggy Lee
column37: who years after the film's 1955 theatrical issue
column38: successfully sued Disney for her fair share of residuals from the videocassette release. ~ Hal Erickson
